indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Number of risks and hazards assessments prepared and number of hazard/risk maps produced. Number of disaster scenarios and simulation models developed. Gender considerations incorporated in therisks and hazard assessments Number of municipalities with vulnerability reduced and capacity strengthened Number of small scale risk reduction works executed Number of children and students educated Number of communication personnel and media representatives trained Number of visits of the interactive hazards map

baseline.comment:
Regulation on Methodology for Assessment of all risks and hazards adopted in January 2011
No integrated and multi-hazard risk assessment in the country
Insufficient technical knowledge and expertise for risks and hazards assessment Initial emergency response drills and trainings executed in selected municipalities. Initial small scale disaster risk – reduction works executed in selected municipalities Limited number of relevant publication exist DRR is not part of the school curricula

target.comment: E-assessment web application developed and risk and hazard assessment process supported through GIS presentation of applications and databases. Integrated risk and hazard assessments as a tools for planning, timely and coordinated decision-making, prevention and response to disasters and accidents finalized in 62 municipalities. Local level risk management plans and works scaled up in 3 municipalities. DRR mainstreaming initiated in selected municipalities in South West and South East regions. Local investment in disaster and climate risk reduction increased followed by enhanced public confidence in institutions and measures. Concept for Disability Inclusive DRR developed and demonstration work replicated and scaled up. Interactive hazard map published. Social innovation tool for advocacy and awareness raising designed. National Disaster Risk Reduction Strategy prepared and adopted by the Government.

actual.comment: E-Assessment web application was successfully designed and developed and integrated risk and hazard assessment in the country is supported through GIS presentation of applications and databases. Accordingly, 100 staff from the CMC and its regional offices were trained on the application. Integrated risk and hazard assessments as tools for planning, timely and coordinated decision-making, prevention and response to disasters and accidents was finalized in 62 municipalities. With this risk and hazard assessment process on the local level was finalized with 81 municipalities having the integrated risk and hazard assessments. Local level risk management work successfully finalized in the Municipality of Veles and scaled up in the Municipality of Prilep with significant cost sharing ratio (70% municipality – 30% UNDP). Interest from the municipalities from two regions expressed. Activities will continue in 2015. Local investment in disaster and climate risk reduction increased followed by enhanced public confidence in institutions and measures continued in the participating municipalities. A set of educational materials prepared, evacuation plans and signs designed and installed for the students with hearing impairment in the state schools in Skopje and Bitola. Video clips for increased awareness on behaviors and procedures during disasters on sign language produced. Interactive risk and hazard maps developed within the framework of the E-Assessment application and the MKFFIS GIS portal. Activities resulted in designing of a new regional project intervention in MKD, Armenia and Moldova in ICT Innovation for DRR. Also, the proxy data approach will be piloted through the regional ECIS big data intervention. Information and knowledge on social innovation on DRR shared with COs in the region. Through coordination with the Crisis Management Centre and participation of the Working group, the final text of the National DRR Strategy and the Action Plan were prepared and are rea

target.comment: National Integrated risk and hazard assessment as a tool for planning, timely and coordinated decision-making, prevention and response to disasters and accidents finalized Local level risk management plans and works finalized in the Municipality of Prilep DRR mainstreaming initiated in selected municipalities Interactive hazard maps published National Disaster Risk Reduction Strategy adopted

actual.comment:
Final draft version of the first ever national risk and hazard assessment for the country through a participatory approach was prepared. This document is based on the already adopted 81 municipal risk and hazard assessments and accordingly the country’s risk and hazard profile was defined. This national assessment shall serve as a tool for DRR mainstreaming in national strategies, policies and programmes. Accordingly, the process of adoption of the national assessment will continue through the Assessment Group and the Steering Committee.
The National DRR Strategy was submitted to the Government for adoption. However, due to the declared crisis situation re: migrants and the existing political situation in the country, it was not put on the agenda for adoption. However, it will be one of the first national DRR strategies adopted after Sendai WCDRR.
Citizens of Prilep are more resilient to storm water flooding with the rehabilitation of the storm water Channel Markovi Kuli. For the first time as a partner for cost-sharing of small scale disaster risk reduction works we had a public enterprise. This is important not only for leveraging the project partners, but also due to the fact that the public enterprise is directly responsible for maintenance of the operation of the storm water channel. Also during the execution of the civil construction works, three workers from the local Roma community of Trizla were engaged by the Contractor.
Hazard maps are developed through the GIS Platform in CMC and can be generated.

iati-activity.description: To help ensure better protection and support to the victims of domestic violence.

iati-activity.title: Institutional response to DV
iati-activity.description: Improving institutional and community response to gender based violence and domestic violence.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Designed model for multi-agency cooperation in high risk cases of domestic violence 2. Joint protocol for dealing with DV cases developed

baseline.comment: 1. Inefficient multi-agency cooperation in high risk DV cases at local level. 2. Existing protocol for dealing with DV victims from 2012 needs alignment with the legal provisions of the new Law on Prevention, Combatting and Protection from Domestic Violence

target.comment: Project started in 2015

1. Establish model for multi-agency response in protecting high-risk cases of domestic violence in at least 3 municipalities in the country 2. Develop a joint protocol for coordinated and multi-sector response to high-risk domestic violence cases

actual.comment:
1. UNDP in coordination with UN Women supported the governmental inter-ministerial working group to develop relevant bylaws that would support efficient implementation of the legal provisions envisaged with the Law on prevention and protection of domestic violence in 2014.
2. The Joint protocol establishes the legal background for the development of the multi-agency cooperation in high-risk domestic violence cases on a local level. This referral mechanism has been tested in three selected municipalities (Kavadarci, Kumanovo and Stip) to avoid duplication of procedures among institutions and to ensure prevention from re-victimization.

iati-activity.description: Active labour market measures targeting the socially excluded developed and implemented.
iati-activity.participating-org: GOVERNMENT OF MACEDONIA, THE FORMER YUGO

iati-activity.description: Promoting Sustainable Employments IV and Supporting the Government in the implementation of the Operational Plan for Labour Market Services and Active Employment Programmes and Measures for 2015

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
1. Number of start-ups supported % of women employed % of young people (aged up to 29) employed % of Roma employed % of start-ups established by people with disabilities
2. Number of participants who completed the training on business plans development
3. Number of additional jobs created in successful small companies % of young staff (aged up to 29) employed % women employed % of supported initiatives that will enable the development of innovative solutions
4. Number of active Youth Info Clubs;
5. Number of downloads of PRV.mk mobile application and number of PRV.MK website visitors
6. Number of individuals at risk of social exclusion who received support through the Community Works Programme % of young people (aged up to 29) who received support through the Community Works Programme % of increase in the number of end beneficiaries (recipients of social services) of the Community Works Programme
7. Number of participants who attended the training on providing professional services to the elderly and obtained a certificate/ license, as part of the Community Works Programme
8. Number of companies supported with a concrete plan for enhanced marketing and presentation of products and services
9. Number of tools developed and provided for local partners to improve monitoring and real time reporting on Employment Programmes' results
10. Number of sector-specific and/or local/regional skills needs assessment studies conducted and curriculum design supported in sectors with high employment opportunities for the disadvantaged;
11. A model and procedures for training provision to people facing social exclusion developed

baseline.comment:
1. The SME sector is facing difficulties in terms of growth and new jobs generation. Since 2007, the Employment Generation Programme helped create over 6,700 new start-ups. 36% of the newly created start-ups are being run by women and 28.4% by young people Self-employment measure targeting people with disabilities has been implemented for the first time in the country by UNDP
2. Since 2007. over 8,300 people have acquired entrepreneurship skills by attending trainings organized by UNDP supported projects
3. Micro and small enterprises (MSEs) limited in their ability to grow and thus hire more workers. In 2014, 82 micro and small companies received help to expand their business, creating additional 119 jobs. Since 2007, 306 MSEs have been supported and 446 new long-term jobs have been created.
4. The activity rate among young people aged 15-24 is extremely low, i.e. 30.6%, which is almost one third of that of persons aged 25-49 (80.1% in Q42014). 4 Youth Info Clubs at four technical faculties have been opened in the country in 2014.
5. 1,530 active users of PRV.mk; 6,500 application downloads; over 1,5 million web site visitors
6. In the period from 2012 to 2014, 220 unemployed people got 6 months short-term employment. In average, 70% of them are women and app. 40% are youth (aged up to 29 years);
7. N/A
8. Lack of supporting activities in the area of marketing and promotion to help the growth of micro and small companies
9. National partners need to enhance their capacity for providing e-services to registered unemployed persons
10. National partners need to improve their capacities for more active cooperation with the private sector and its direct involvement in local level labour market analyses
11. The Adult Education Centre is still not fully operational; institutions' responsibilities are not yet clearly defined, there is lack of coordination between different institutions; There are no procedures for the implementation of educational activitie

target.comment: Project started in 2015

1. Provide technical assistance and advice in the process of designing the National Employment Strategy and follow-up programmes that accelerate employment and quality jobs creation for all; 900 self-employments/small businesses established and 60 additional created - 30% young people aged up to 29 - 38% women - 20 Roma - 120 companies established by persons with disability (2016)
2. Strengthening entrepreneurship and management capacities of 1,500 unemployed people in business planning and financial management; Additional 150 people with disabilities will receive training on business management. Barriers and risks and mentoring services will be provided to those that will establish a business during the first year (2016)
3. Up to 200 additional jobs supported in the previously established companies
4. 5 Youth Info Clubs supported in university centers throughout the country
5. Number of young people who use the mobile application PRV.MK
6. Support the establishment of local partnerships for provision of social services to vulnerable groups that will create part-time employment for 300 hard to employ job-seekers.
7. Training of 50 people to provide professional services to the elderly through the Community Works Programme

actual.comment:
1. 942 people received coaching, training and small grants to start their own business. 35% of these new entrepreneurs are women and 29% are young people aged up to 29. Out of the 12 unemployed Roma who successfully completed the Self-Employment Programme, 9 started their new businesses.
2. 1,332 unemployed candidates underwent a training for strengthening their entrepreneurship and management skills and 1,256 obtained a certificate for successfully completing the training.
3. 72 micro and small companies received help to expand their businesses, creating another 111 jobs.
4. Contracts with 4 Youth Info Clubs were extended in 4 university centers. 1,732 students obtained information about job opportunities. The architectural design of the fifth Youth Info Club is developed and ready to be implemented in 2016 once a mutual agreement with the Faculty of Mechanical Engineering is reached.
5. PRV.mk is a smart application that brings the latest job openings directly to a mobile phone, including internships and volunteer positions. The app is functional for three mobile operating systems (Android, iOS and Windows Phone). Over 7,100 downloads and around 1,400 active users are registered by Play Store (Android). A new, advanced version of PRV.mk 2.0 has been introduced to all users, which will bring the latest news, tips and hints and other opportunities closer to young people.
6. The Community Works Programme supported 42 municipalities in tackling social exclusion on two fronts at once. Implemented by the Government, municipalities and UNDP, the Programme offered opportunities to 318 unemployed people to gain valuable skills while also providing social services to the most socially excluded groups in the country. Out of the 318 beneficiaries, 43% are young unemployed, aged up to 29. Over 10,000 socially excluded people in 42 municipalities have felt the benefits from the services provided through the Programme, with each municipality launching schemes of part-t

iati-activity.title: Promote Sustain. Employment 3
iati-activity.description: The programme will contribute to efficient implementation of the 2014 Operational Plan on ALMMs and its components

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
1. Number of start-ups supported % of women employed % of youth aged up to 29 No. of Roma employed
2. Number of additional jobs created in successful small companies 3. Number of established Youth Info Clubs 4. Number of jobs created for unemployed men and women that belong to the hard to employ group. 5. Number of unemployed that went through the training programme; Number of new training programmes verified

baseline.comment: 1. The SME sector is facing difficulties in terms of growth and generation of new jobs generation. Since 2007, over 5,800 start-ups have been created through the program; 36% of the new start-ups are being run by women and 28.4% by young people A self-employment measure targeting people with disabilities has been implemented for the first time by UNDP 2. Micro and small companies (MSCs) are constrained in their ability to grow and hire more workers. 3. The activity rate of young people (15-24) is roughly half of the activity rate of adults (34.7% in 2013) 4. Unemployed vulnerable face difficulties and barriers when it comes to jobs seeking and employment. 5. There is a lack of programmes that can help match the needs of the local labour market with the qualified labour force

target.comment: 1. 900 small businesses established and 50 additional employments created in new small businesses i. 30% of job seekers are in the age category of 29 and below ii. 38% are women iii. 20 Roma 2. Up to 100 additional employments supported; 60% in micro businesses 3. Support provided for the creation of partnerships with academia and private sector to help bridge the gap between young graduates and the job market 4. Community service programme providing temporary employment for 100 job seekers from the vulnerable groups 5. Over 200 unemployed people trained in skills on demand on the labor market; 20 new standardized training programmes available

actual.comment: 1. Coaching, training, mentoring and small start­up grants helped 940 unemployed people set up their own small businesses, creating 1,050 jobs; 36% of the newly created businesses are being run by women and 28.4% by young people 2. 82 micro and small companies received help to expand their businesses, creating another 119 jobs 3. 4 Youth Info Clubs have been established in university centers throughout the country; 1,300 students have obtained information about job opportunities; A mobile application PRV.MK has been developed to enable young people have access to real­time information on available jobs, internships and apprenticeship opportunities 4. Supported part-time engagement of 142 long­term unemployed (41% of them under 29) in 30 municipalities to deliver social services to vulnerable groups 5. 232 unemployed candidates completed vocational training courses in high­demand occupations. Initiated work on a system for adult primary education that will deliver equivalency diplomas and provide educational programmes adapted to adult needs

iati-activity.description: Technical assistance for preparation of the third national report on climate change aim to strengthen the capacity of the key national institutions to integrate climate change priorities into country development strategies and relevant sector programs.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: • GHG inventory with Tier 2 data for key sources • Establishment of continuous data measurement and analysis system • Complete inventory chapter for the TNC • Number of studies available to inform different institutions and sectors about feasible adaptation policies and measures and their potential prioritization to facilitate decision making; • Upgraded V&A chapter of the TNC • Number of studies available to inform different institutions and sectors about feasible mitigation policies and measures and their potential prioritization to facilitate decision making • Upgraded mitigation chapter in the TNC • % of targeted institutions with improved capacity to take proposed mitigation and adaptation policies and measures forward • % of targeted stakeholder groups that express increased awareness on climate change concerns

baseline.comment: First and Second National Communication to UNFCCC adopted by the Government and submitted to the UNFCCC Secretariat, inventory of GHG emission for the period 1990 – 1998; update of GHG inventory through targeting specifuc sectors; National Strategy for Energy Development for the Period 2008-2020 with a Vision to 2030 adopted; National Strategy for Energy Efficiency in the Republic of Macedonia till 2020” (adopted in 2010); a new Law on Energy was adopted in February 2011; National Strategy for Sustainable Development (adopted in 2010); National Environmental Investments Strategy (2009); the National Environmental Approximation Strategy (2008); National Health Strategy for Adaptation in Health Sector (NHSAHS) (2010); a National Strategy for Climate Change Adaptation in Agriculture; Assessing the economic impact of climate change prepared.

target.comment:
The Strategic Environmental Assessment of the Third National Communication on Climate Change successfully finalized.
The Third National Communication on Climate Change adopted by the Government and officially submitted to UNFCCC

actual.comment: The Third National Communication on Climate Change adopted by the Government and submitted to UNFCCC in March 2014

iati-activity.title: Introducing Integrity Systems
iati-activity.description: Helping citizens get an easy, friendly, equitable and corruption-free access to services provided by central and local level institutions.

document-link.title: Project Fact Sheet National and Local Integrity Systems
Annual Project Report National and Local Integrity Systems

iati-activity.title: Introducing Integrity Systems
iati-activity.description: Introducing Integrity Systems

Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
Development of the methodological framework for integrity assessments
Actual conducting of the integrity risk assessments
Provision of training for local stakeholders in 10 municipalities
Small grants scheme developed and implemented
Innovative social accountability solutions offered by civil society and media
Comprehensive capacity building programme designed for the State Commission for Prevention of Corruption
Priority/immediate capacity needs addressed, basic IT tools introduced for streamlining of processes

baseline.comment: -Lack of social accountability mechanisms at local level; isolated and non-sustainable efforts -Low political commitment to the anti-corruption agenda at local level, lack of integrity instruments to hold the local authorities accountable -Low awareness at local level of the corruption risks and importance of integrity systems -Lack of data and mehodologies/tools to monitor corruption risks at local level.

target.comment: -Prototyping IT-based innovative social accountability solutions for improved transparency in 5 municipalities -Ensuing broad local level political commitment to the anti-corruption agenda, by having 2/3 of Mayors sign the anti-corruption policy as a first step towards introduction of integrity systems -Organization of five local level awareness events and two major national integrity events -Testing and codification of the two new methodologies for monitoring corruption risks and integrity at local level (Responsibility, Transparency and Accountability Index and Local Government Integrity Index).

actual.comment: -Innovative IT based social accountability solutions prototyped in 5 municipalities to gather citizens' feedback on the issues related to transparency, accountability and openness -47 municipalities, of a total of 81 (nearly 2/3) signed the anti-corruption policy (integrity charters), as a first step towards introduction of full-fledged integrity systems. -Five local level awareness raising events and two major national integrity events were organized in partnership with municipalities, civil society and youth. -Two new methodologies for monitoring corruption resilience at local level (Responsibility, Transparency and Accountability Index and Local Government Integrity Index) were tested and transferred to the State Anti-Corruption Commission for further institutionalization.

iati-activity.title: LOCAL DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMME
iati-activity.description: Local Action for Inclusive Development
iati-activity.participating-org: GOVERNMENT OF MACEDONIA, THE FORMER YUGO

iati-activity.title: Local Development Programme
iati-activity.description: This is a preparatory assistance project. The overall objective of this project is to intensify integrated local and regional development of the country by providing assistance for enhancement of the local inclusive community based development framework.
iati-activity.participating-org: GOVERNMENT OF MACEDONIA, THE FORMER YUGO

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Number of specific assessments. Number of knowledge transfer tools, including tailor made training modules and number of trainees. Number of action plans addressing immediate needs of local stakeholders. Number of ICT interventions that enable open access to user-friendly information on local public expenditures. Number of social audits of local services and public expenditures performed. Number of partnerships between civil society organizations and public entities established. Number of Inter-Municipal Cooperation forms established. Number of services and policy products produced and delivered by the established Inter-Municipal Cooperation forms. Number of social entrepreneurship partnerships of Civil Society Organization and public and private entities. Number of local Commissions for Equal Opportunities that operate more frequently, effectively and efficiently. Number of recommendations for a local and regional policy action on climate change mitigation and adaptation.

baseline.comment: Limited local/planning region institutional capacities for inclusive governance and community based local and regional development. Limited funds for implementation of the Capacity Development Programme and Action Plan for improvement of the integrated local/planning region governance system of the Vardar Planning Region. Lack of comprehensive reporting on the financing of local services and limited access to user-friendly information on local public expenditures. Limited use of IT and social media for delivery of local services. Lack of regional and local funds to support operations and scaling up of the existing Inter-Municipal Cooperation forms and establishment of new Inter-Municipal Cooperation forms and social partnerships in the Vardar Planning region Lack of state incentives for establishment and functioning of Inter-Municipal Cooperation and social partnerships. The Ministry of Local Self-Government did not start updating and maintaining the established Inter-Municipal Cooperation knowledge management system and the E-evidence of established Inter-Municipal Cooperation forms and forms of international cooperation of the municipalities. Limited information on the needs of the vulnerable segments of the local communities related to their participation in local/regional governance processes. Local Commissions for Equal Opportunities do not operate frequently, effectively and efficiently. Lack of performance indicators to monitor and evaluate the progress in addressing the vulnerabilities as well as the quality of the most critical local services. Limited number of partnerships of the local/regional authorities with the private sector and civil society. Lack of social entrepreneurship initiatives and programmes. Limited bottom up generated evidence and efforts for down-streaming the programming of the local economic development and regional competitiveness as well as the agriculture and rural development in accordance with the respective chapters of the EU

target.comment: Preparation of a report for analysis of municipal revenues and expenditures for 2013/2014 to collect data on the trends regarding the financing of municipalities and enabling corrective actions. Publishing of the integral Report on the Status of the Implementation of the Decentralization Programme 2011 – 2014 to share information on the priority policy measures with relevant stakeholders and the general public. Preparation and delivery of three priority training modules from the Programme of Work of the Network for Inclusive Development of the Vardar Planning Region to continue the process of development of the critical capacities of regional stakeholders for inclusive and integrated development programming and planning. Organization of the 2014 Partnership Day of the Vardar Planning Region in order to continue with mobilization of resources for implementation of the regional development priority actions. Creation of an electronic portal for youth on the web page of the Center for Development of the Vardar Planning Region with information about the institutional forms of support and participation of young people in local governance to increase the opportunities for effective networking and address the needs of the young population. Creation and implementation of a social marketing campaign for employment of five best students from the Vardar Planning Region as an innovative tool for creation of employment opportunities for young people. Organizing at least one promotional event and provision of support for preparation of at least one project proposal of the Joint Energy Efficiency Unit of the Vardar Planning Region to demonstrate effective solutions, achieving measurable economy of scale due to the cooperation at a planning region level. At least one mission for transferring knowledge, skills and best practices from Croatia (UNDP Regional Facility) on the EU Acquis Chapters 11, 12 and/or 22 organized.

actual.comment: In order to increase the knowledge and skills in the critical areas for local development, the capacities of civil servants from of 13 municipalities were strengthened through the delivery of a tailor-made training course on Local Economic Development by the leading Faculty of Economy in Skopje. Fiscal Decentralization Reports for 2013 and the first half of 2014 were prepared and the Ministry of Finance was assisted in undertaking a comparative review and analyses of the fiscal decentralization process and financing of the municipalities in the country, the SEE countries and a selected number of EU member states. The first youth related web portal at a planning region level “www.mladivpr.mk “was designed and is administered by the Center for Development of the Vardar Planning Region. The web site contains information about institutional support for young people, as well as participation opportunities for youth in local governance. The organization of the third “Partners Day” of the Vardar Planing region served for dissemination of the information on the results achieved by the Network for Inclusive Development of the region, for consolidation of the existing partnerships and creation of new partnerships. Through a joint mobilization of resources of the Veles municipality, the Centre for Development of the Vardar Planning Region and the private sector, the seat of the Inclusive Network in Veles was refurbished and officially opened, thus confirming the commitment of the partners to the mission and the objectives of the Network In order to demonstrate the effects from application of modern technological solutions for energy efficiency, 16 solar panels were purchased and installed in kindergartens and elementary schools in the nine (9) municipalities of the Vardar Planning region. A Social Marketing Campaign for employing 5 best students from the region in the companies from the Vardar planning region was designed. The capacities of the Network for Inclusive Devel

target.comment: A report analyzing municipal revenues and expenditures for 2014/2015 was prepared to collect data on the trends regarding the financing of municipalities and enable corrective actions.. Guidance and support for the implementation of one priority action from the 2014 – 2016 Programme of the Network for Inclusive Development of the Vardar Planning Region provided. Inter-municipal cooperation for provision of care to vulnerable groups in the municipalities of Veles, Kavadarci, Gradsko, Chaska and Rosoman and r addressing the priority needs of people with disabilities established, to enable economy of scale and delivery of new and innovative local services An elevator for people with disabilities purchased and installed in the seat of the municipality of Kavadarci and another elevator for children with disabilities purchased and installed in one elementary school in the municipality of Veles to demonstrate solutions for overcoming physical barriers and increasing the mobility of the people with disabilities Recreational equipment for people with disabilities purchased and installed in one recreational site in each of the Veles, Kavadarci, Gradsko, Chaska and Rosoman municipalities to create better conditions for recreation of people with disabilities.

actual.comment: The Reports analyzing municipal revenues and expenditures for 2014/ and the first half of 2015 were prepared. Organization of the third “Partners Day” in the Vardar Planning region was supported – the event will be held in the forst quarter of 2016 Inter-municipal cooperation for provision of care to vulnerable groups in the municipalities of Veles, Kavadarci, Gradsko, Chaska and Rosoman and for addressing the priority needs of people with disabilities was established. Elevator for pupils with disabilities was purchased and installed in one primary school in Veles. In addition a lavatory in the school was refurbished. In the frame of the campaign to raise public awareness about people with special needs and disabilities a one-day visit to the St. Georgia monastery in Negotino was organized for more than 70 people with special needs and disabilities of all ages by the NGO - Association of people with cerebral paralyses – Veles. Equipment for exercise of persons with special needs and disabilities were purchased and installed in Veles Youth Park and Kavadarci Park. Construction of gazebos for people with disabilities and landscaping of the area around them in municipalities of Veles, Kavadarci, Rosoman, Cashka and Gradsko was completed.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Number of youth organizations participating in the development of the National Youth Strategy 2. Number of Local Youth Councils participating in the development of the National Youth Strategy 3. Number of activities and events organized on social cohesion among youth 4. Number of events on youth participation in decision-making 5. Number of staff in central and local government in charge of responding to youth questions and queries 6. Regulation of youth work initiated, developed and adopted

baseline.comment: 1. Lack of interest among stakeholders to involve youth in policy making and lack of systemic mechanisms to ensure youth participation in decision making 2.Lack of innovative tools to increase youth informing 3.Lack of youth involvement in promotion of SDG/post 2015 agenda 4. Low level of engagement of vulnerable youth groups

target.comment: 1. At least 5 local youth policies are developed together with youth participatory bodies recognized as partners in policy dialogue 2. At least 2 Innovative techniques are used to increase the level of youth informing 3. At least 100 youth are taking an active role in promoting the post-2015 agenda and the sustainable development goals 4. At least 20 young people belonging to vulnerable and excluded youth groups become more included in youth related processes

actual.comment: 1. Five local strategies developed jointly between municipal staff and local youth councils 2. A mobile and web application share information on latest jobs, internships and training opportunities for youth 3.Over 3000 young people take part in Youth events promoting the post 2015 agenda and the sustainable development goals 4. 30 Youth with special needs attended human rights and youth participation workshops and trainings

target.comment: 1. At least 60 youth organizations and informal groups actively participate in the process for development of the new National Youth Strategy (2016-2025) 2. At least 6 local youth councils actively participate in the process for development of the new National Youth Strategy (2016-2025) 3. At least 50 events/workshops are organized on youth participation in decision making 4. A new National Youth Strategy is adopted by the Government (by December 2015) 5. A National Action Plan for the new National Youth Strategy (2016-2020) is developed 6. At least 20 different activities to support social cohesion among youth in multi-ethnic societies are organized, with provision of direct support and capacity building of local youth councils and local youth CSOs.

actual.comment: 1. Over 95 youth organizations and informal groups actively involved in the development of the new National Youth Strategy (2016-2025) 2. 11 local youth councils actively participated in the development of the new National Youth Strategy (2016-2025) 3. 65 workshops, public debates, local meetings and discussions were organized on youth participation in decision making 4. Draft National Youth Strategy submitted for adoption to the Government 5. Draft 5 year Action Plan for the new National Youth Strategy (2016-2020) developed 6. 30 workshops, trainings, street art performances and debates held, specifically aimed at supporting social cohesion among youth in multi-ethnic societies. Trainings provided direct support and capacity building of local youth councils and local youth CSOs.

iati-activity.title: Prespa Lake Ecosystem Restoration
iati-activity.description: Restoration of the Prespa Lake Ecosystem

iati-activity.title: Prespa Lake Restoration
iati-activity.description: Contribution to the improvement of the Prespa Lake’s Ecological State and its Resilience

transaction.disbursement-channel: Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: At least 8% reduction of nutrient loads (and other substances) to the lake as a result of the gradual increase of project supported measures % of hectares under Good Agricultural Practices and/or agro-ecological measures $ of area under nature-based systems (wetlands, river corridors, buffers) Quantity of collected pesticide packaging and biodegradable waste Functional Watershed Management Committee as a formal cross-sectoral participatory mechanism for integrated watershed management # of knowledge products (manuals, guidance documents, lessons learnt booklets, fact sheets and articles)

baseline.comment: High proportion of the delineated water bodies in the Prespa Lake watershed doesn’t meet the requirement of having ‘good’ ecological status according to the existing regulations Important natural landscape elements (ecotones) are being destroyed over the past decades as a result of development pressures The current nutrient loads of anthropogenic origin (500 t/year) exceed the levels the lake ecosystem can absorb without further degrading Unsustainable farming practices, especially overuse of pesticides, fertilizers and irrigation water No sufficient monitoring and management capacities exist at present The current organizational structure and capacity of Municipality of Resen and other responsible organizations / institutions doesn’t meet the needs of an integrated watershed management system Low level of awareness about nature protection and sustainable use of natural resources

target.comment:
1.Official launching of the native forest nursery
2. Finalization of the hydrogeological (groundwater study)
3. Finalization of the first cycle of the agroecological farming grants programme
4. Finalization of the wetland restoration study
5. Operationalization of the wastewater management system in Nakolec
6. Completion of the energy efficiency measures in municipal building
7. Launching of the Lake Monitoring and Management Station

actual.comment: Native forest nursery fully operational. In 2014, approx. 400,000 seedlings and planting material was produced and used for forest regeneration of over 45 ha in the Prespa region. The hydrogeological (groundwater) study completed thus providing valuable information for planning of the irrigation management in the watershed. Twenty (20) farmers got grant for implementation of agro-ecological farming measures focused on controlled use of agrochemicals and use of water for irrigation. The wetland restoration study completed and the conceptual design for the selected alternative has been elaborated. The wastewater management system in Nakolec is been completed, and it provides evacuation of wastewaters from a community of 500 inhabitants The renovated municipal building with energy efficiency measures generates annual saving of approx. 20,000 USD The Lake Monitoring and Management Station has been established and the staff performs a continuous lake and watershed monitoring programme

target.comment: Completion of Phase 2 of the Eutrophication study: Model development and application of alternative management scenarios Implementation of the 2 cycle of agro-ecological farming practices measures in Prespa and inclusion of at least 40 new farmers in the grant scheme (at least 5 of them female). Final decision on the scope of wetland restoration reached and start of implementation of the wetland restoration alternative Implementation of Priority erosion control measures implemented on an area of at least 40 ha of forest land Implementation of at least 10 community driven small-scale infrastructure projects Regular monitoring reports generated by the Lake Monitoring Station

actual.comment: The Eutrophication study: Model development and application of alternative management scenarios completed Implementation of the 2 cycle of agro-ecological farming practices measures in Prespa successfully completed with inclusion of total 77 farmers in two cycles, out of which 10 female farmers Alternative solutions for implementation of the wetland restoration elaborated and decision on the final solution of wetland restoration reached Priority erosion control measures implemented on an area of 40 ha of forest land 10 community driven small-scale infrastructure projects (reconstruction of water supply and sewage collection systems, small eco-parks in two villages, etc) implemented in the municipality of Resen The Lake Monitoring Station in Stenje fully operational and regularly generates monitoring reports for the Prespa Lake

iati-activity.description: The project aims at improving energy efficiency on a municipal level and enhanced awareness and capacities of stakeholders involved in municipal energy management issues.

iati-activity.description: The Project aims at implementing energy efficiency measures in at least 2 buildings to showcase the benefits of EE, strengthening the municipal authorities' capacity for energy management, and upgrading the software for municipal energy management

Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) The staff of the Energy Efficiency Department within the Municipality of Karposh is trained in municipal energy management and is regularly using the energy management system. An effective system for remote sensing is in place and is in regular use. The ExCITE software is regularly used and updated. 2) A number of cost-effective energy efficiency measures are implemented in the selected buildings (school and kindergarten). The early measurement and verification show decrease in energy use and costs. 3) Upgrades of ExCITE software has been developed pursuing the legal requirements and in a consultation process with the municipalities. The municipalities are regularly using the upgraded version of the software in their monitoring and management of energy. 4) At least two additional municipalities entered in cost-sharing agreement with UNDP for implementation of efficiency measures and/ or introduction of systematic energy management practices.

baseline.comment: 1) The Municipality of Karposh is a pioneer vis-à-vis the establishment of a system and organizational structure for municipal energy monitoring and management. The Municipality of Karposh has established and staffed a separate Energy Efficiency Department, and expressed its commitment to streamline the energy management by developing a remote sensing system. 2) The Municipality of Karposh expressed its commitment to finance and implement energy efficiency measures in two public buildings (a school and a kindergarten) on a cost-sharing arrangement with UNDP. 3) The ExCITE software has been developed and is in use. The amendments to the Energy Law are expected to make the use and regular update of ExCITE mandatory for all municipalities. The municipalities have expressed their interest in upgrading the software which would allow them an effective monitoring and management of energy use. 4) A number of municipalities have expressed strong interest to implement energy efficiency measures and/ or introduce energy management systems on a cost-sharing arrangement with UNDP.

target.comment: 1. Upgraded version of the ExCITE software to match the requirements of the Rulebook on the IT system for monitoring of energy consumption in public institutions developed 2. Partnerships in the area of energy efficiency on a cost-sharing arrangement established with at least two municipalities 3. Implementation of energy efficiency measures in at least two municipal buildings 4. Knowledge and capacities for energy efficiency management on local level improved

actual.comment: The ExCITE software upgraded to match the requirements of the Rulebook on the IT system for monitoring of energy consumption in public institutions Partnerships in the area of energy efficiency established with two municipalities and additional resources for implementation of EE measures mobilized Energy efficiency measures implemented in two public buildings

target.comment: New partnership with local governments established or expanded and energy efficiency measures implemented in at least two public buildings (schools and/or kindergartens)

actual.comment: Energy efficiency measures were implemented in one kindergarten in the municipality of Kisela Voda, and the high School in the City of Skopje, and new alternative source of heating was ensured for one school in the municipality of Karposh. All activities were implemented on a cost-sharing basis between UNDP and the municipalities, and majority of the funds were provided by the municipality while UNDP was mostly providing advice and technical support.

iati-activity.description: To assist the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia in the preparation of its First Biennial Update Report (FBUR) for the fullfilment of the obligations under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC).

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: • National circumstances and institutional arrangements relevant to the preparation of the national communications updated • Updated GHG inventory • Continuous data measurement and analysis system established • Number of studies available to inform different institutions and sectors about feasible mitigation policies and measures and their potential prioritization to facilitate decision making • Upgraded mitigation chapter in the FBUR • Technology, financial and capacity needs for mitigation assessment. • A case study for mitigation potential - switching from conventional fuel to natural gas, showing the economic and environmental benefits • Information on national resources allocated for climate change upon ratification of the UNFCCC • Relevant training curricula and number of trained individuals • Options for establishment of a domestic MRV system analyzed • Process for establishment of national institutional and legal frameworks for domestic MRV initiated.

baseline.comment: • Initial and Second National Communications on climate change endorsed and submitted to UNFCCC, Third National Communication under development • Outline of the national circumstances as part of the TNC (2013) • Inventories for the period 1990 – 2009 revised • Sectoral studies/reports for the mitigation potential in the respective sectors • Mitigation scenarios as part of the TNC • Technology, financial and capacity needs for mitigation report as part of the TNC. • Initial analyses done and a roadmap for MRV developed

target.comment: • National circumstances and institutional arrangements relevant to the preparation of the national communications updated • GHG inventory for 2012 prepared, and inventories for the period 1990 - 2009 recalculated, using the UNFCCC recommended 2006 software • Mitigation actions and their effects, including associated methodologies and assumptions, and progress of implementation described as per the guidelines • Constraints and gaps identified; related financial, technology and capacity building needs assessed; and recommendation for addressing the needs provided • Establishment of domestic Measurement, Reporting and Verification arrangements supported; • First Biennial Update Report Compiled and sent to UNFCCC

First Biennial Update Report adopted by the Government and submitted to UNFCCC;
Intended Nationally Determined Contributions (INDCs) adopted by the Government and timely submitted to the UNFCCCC

actual.comment:
The First Biennial Update Report adopted by the Government and submitted to the UNFCCC in February 2015;
The Intended Nationally Determined Contributions (INDCs) adopted by the Government and submitted to the UNFCCCC in August 2015, prior to the 21st CoP in Paris

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Comprehensive citizens’ satisfaction survey designed and implemented. At least one consultative event organized to discuss the survey results. Crosscutting analyses prepared and decentralization strategic framework adjusted. A partnership programme designed and implemented. Local e-services study prepared. At least one consultative event organized to discuss the results. Local e-services road-map prepared. In-depth analysis of the existing Inter –Municipal Cooperation practices and the current Inter –Municipal Cooperation policies presented to the Government. Best Inter –Municipal Cooperation practice award established and at least two Inter –Municipal Cooperation arrangements supported. Assessment report on the possibility to establish a Unit for Support of Private Enterprises within the Centers for Regional Development, prepared. New Decentralization Programme for the period 2015 – 2020, prepared.

baseline.comment: No updated data and analyses of citizens’ perceptions on the quality of local services, resulting in policies and actions that do not reflect citizens’ priority needs. Lack of innovative partnership programme to address service delivery. No updated and sufficient data and analyses of existing local e-services and related needs and opportunities. Inter –Municipal Cooperation evidence system established. Mid-term decentralization policy review completed. Lack of state financial support for Inter –Municipal Cooperation, resulting in insufficient utilization of this tool for alternative service delivery. Centers for development of the planning regions face serious sustainability issues due to an inappropriate financing system. The existing decentralization programme expires in 2014, which creates a risk for the country to remain without a very important policy for the development of its local self-government system.

target.comment: Comprehensive information on citizens’ satisfaction with decentralization services made available to ensure that regional and local development policies are developed on an informed basis. An innovative Programme for Support of Partnerships between municipalities, civil society and business sector put into practice, ensuring involvement of all relevant local development stakeholders and actors. A study on existing e-services at local level and needs and possibilities for introduction of new e-services carried out, with recommendations for modernizing and increasing effectiveness and efficiency of local services. The mechanisms for support and promotion of Inter –Municipal Cooperation improved and new Inter –Municipal Cooperation practices operationalized to increase the economy of scale in the delivery of local services Assessment of opportunities for service delivery to private sector by the Centers for Development of Planning Regions completed and used for diversifying the portfolio of services and functions of the Centers. The Program for Sustainable Development of the Local Self-Government for the period 2015 - 2020 prepared in a participatory manner.

actual.comment: A comprehensive Citizens’ Perceptions Survey was carried out and presented to the Government, providing a wealth of information about the level of citizens’ satisfaction with the quality of local services. The first draft of the Study of Local e-Services Delivery was prepared in a participatory manner, including the following research: (1) E-services survey in 44 municipalities; (2) In-depth research regarding the delivery of local e-services in the municipalities of Tetovo, Veles, Cheshinovo - Obleshevo and Dojran; (3) In-depth analyses of web page contents in all municipalities (4) Report on the best international practice on local e-services delivery. The 2014 Report on the Status of the Inter-Municipal Cooperation was prepared. The findings and recommendations will be used for amending the Law on Inter-Municipal Cooperation and adjusting the Inter-Municipal Cooperation policy in order to meet the needs of the municipalities and the local communities. The findings and recommendations from all above described reports will be used for the preparation of the new Programme for Sustainable Local Development and Decentralization 2015 - 2020. The capacities of the Ministry of Local Self-Government for administering the e-register of Inter-Municipal Cooperation were strengthened, creating pre-conditions for an independent and efficient collection of information on the status of the Inter-Municipal Cooperation. With UNDP assistance, the by-law on prioritizing activities of wider relevance and interest that can be realized through inter-municipal cooperation for the period September 2014 - September 2017, was prepared and adopted by the Government, enabling more accurate targeting of the Government’s incentives. The Inclusive Development Network of the Vardar planning region was awarded by the Ministry of Local Self-Government as the best Inter-Municipal Cooperation practice in the country for 2014 and was replicated in the North-East and Pelagonia planning regions, wit

target.comment: The Local e-Services Study finalized and endorsed by the Government to create a basis for the formulation of a new policy for modernization of municipal services The inclusive development networks of the Vardar Pelagonia and Northeast planning regions supported to implement priority actions derived from their Programmes and Action Plans. Technical support provided to the State Inter-Municipal Cooperation Commission for amending the Law on Inter-Municipal Cooperation and the related policy. The Centers for development of the five planning regions (Skopje, Polog, East, Southwest and Southeast Regions) supported in preparation of Programmes, Action Plans and Communication Strategies of the newly established Business Centers for Support of Small and Medium Enterprises . Implementation of activities for increasing regional competitiveness supported. Transfer of international best practices on distribution of state aid for private sector research and development at regional level and attraction of foreign investments enabled through study trip to the Czech Republic and three workshops with Czech experts in the country. Programme for Sustainable Local Development and Decentralization 2015 – 2020 finalized and endorsed by the Government and broadly disseminated. 2015 – 2017 Action Plan of the Programme for Sustainable Local Development and Decentralization 2015 – 2020 and Monitoring Methodology prepared and endorsed by the Government. Third Annual Conference on Sustainable Local Development and Decentralization, organized with the aim to gather all relevant stakeholders in taking stock of the implementation of the decentralization policy in 2015 and formulating joint recommendations and prioritizing actions for 2016. Potentials for development of forms of rural tourism in the four (4) least developed planning regions in the country (Northeast, Vardar, Southwest and Polog) mapped and rural tourism registers prepared, thus creating basis for more accurate preparation

actual.comment:
The final Draft of an Integrated Study on Local e-Services was discussed and endorsed by the Government Committee on e-Services. Integrated Regional Development Network (IRDN) was formed in the Pelagonia Planning Region, and the Platform for Regional Rural Action (PRRA) was established in the Northeast Planning Region. Both Networks prepared Programmes of Work and respective Action Plans and started with the implementation of priority activities. Premises where both Networks operate were refurbished. The Vardar Region Inclusive Network continued with implementation of the 2013 – 2015 Programme of work. Center for Development of Pelagonija Planning Region held 2 promotional events for increasing capacities of the business sector (one workshop on agricultural business and the other workshop on utilization of domestic and foreign financial instruments, organized with the Regional Chamber of Commerce). Centre for Development of Vardar Planning Region held the event for promotion of the three products: the Guide for investors, the Map/Collection of the Industrial Zones and the web portal. The economic operator presented the products before the mayors, as well as representatives of business and civil sector. Based on a pre-prepared analysis of existing practices and current Inter-Municipal Cooperation (IMC), a Draft Law amending the Law on IMC was prepared. The State Inter-Municipal Cooperation Commission was assisted in preparation of the 2015 IMC Status Report. The brochure Inter-Municipal Cooperation in the Republic of Macedonia was published.
Programs for Private Sector Support, including an Action Plan and Communication Plan for Program Implementation were prepared by the Business Centers established for support and advisory services to SMEs in Skopje, Polog, East, Southeast and Southwest Planning Regions. In all 5 Centers, altogether 28 informational events were organized and attended by a total of 1053 participants (586 men and 467 women), most of whom were repre

iati-activity.title: MUNICIPAL COUNCILS SUPPORT
iati-activity.description: This project focus on boosting the local development through improved local revenue capacity and accountable local public expenditures and starts with preparatory assistance/project initation plan.

document-link.title: Initiation Plan - Empowering Municipal Councils Project

iati-activity.title: Initiation P, Mun.Councils
iati-activity.description: This is a preparatory assistance project/initiation plan project focused on boosting the local development through improved local revenue capacity and accountable local public expenditures.

transaction.disbursement-channel: Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Drivers and restrainers of reform change as anticipated by the project description, identified. Participatory programme development process involving key stakeholders from all 81 local self-government units in order to elaborate the programme, initiated. Project Document, elaborated including detailed analysis of each of the proposed interventions on national, and local level, with annexes like log-frame, time schedule (sequencing of components), budget, required resources: personnel, technology, know how. Impact hypothesis and result chains, including outcomes, outputs, activities, and a cost benefit and cost effectiveness analysis of the programme intervention, elaborated as integral part of the Project Document. Programme organization, tasks and responsibilities of all stakeholders steering mechanisms, monitoring system, defined. Risk management: assessment of opportunities, risks and mitigation strategies, defined. Strategy for improving sustainability and opportunities for up scaling, including exit strategy, formulated. Suitable actions for citizen participation in the budgeting processes at municipal level, identified. Tools/manner for cooperation and collaboration with the local implementing partner organization, defined. Indicators for the selection of the municipalities with the most capacity and will to address the need for better knowledge of the municipal councilors about their role and the professional execution of tasks by the municipal administration, developed. Training and capacity building curriculum for the municipal councilors and municipal administration to improve their knowledge of the budgeting process and to increase their accountability towards the citizens in line with the methodology presented in the offer, namely the concept of small wins and avoiding push back, developed and tested in 6-8 municipalities. Cooperation e with the important actors such as the Ministry of Finance, ZELS and international donors active in the same field of c

baseline.comment: Municipal councils often fail to fully perform their functions of oversight, representation and legislation. Strong influence of the party centers strengthened by the lack of local fiscal independence, payment as a perverse incentive for being a council member, underdeveloped networking among the councils, and a lack of demand for accountability from the side of the citizens. Most municipal councils (with a few exceptions) have become voting machines for backing up or opposing the mayor’s decisions. The majority of municipal councilors remain anonymous in the public eye and even within the local governance circles. The National Association of the Municipalities, once a two-chamber body, is now dominated by the mayors. Insufficient education and awareness of councilors for execution of their mandate Disturbed interaction between the executive (mayor and administration) and the decision-making (councils) bodies. Only about 20% of the surveyed councils in 2013 reported that they have initiated citizens’ gatherings or public hearings, and recognize that citizen participation is not at a satisfactory level. Less than 10 councils reported discussing their development programmes with their communities. Only 9 councils reported that they have ever discussed the fiscal gaps between revenues and expenditures, and only 22 of them have discussed debt management issues. Only one council has approved financing of a programme coming from inter-ethnic committee, similar is the situation regarding the council’s committees for consumer protection and gender equality. The Council Finance and Budget committees are the most active, and at least formally they regularly pursue all necessary legal steps for adopting the budgets and the annual accounts.

target.comment: A situation analysis that will identify all stakeholders, confirm the drivers and restrainers of reform, the “positive” and” negative” outliers, potential allies and partners, carried out. Tools for assessment of the state of the local public finance management, gender and inter-ethnic aspects of the work of the municipal councils and the applied innovation in the local governance process, designed and applied. A participatory project development process with all identified stakeholders from the 81 local self-government units, completed. Tools/manner for cooperation and collaboration with the Association of the Finance Officers, defined and cooperation agreement signed. Indicators for the selection of the municipalities to work with during the second – implementation phase of the project, developed. Training and capacity building curriculum for the municipal councilors and municipal administration, developed and tested in 6-8 municipalities. The Project Board established.

actual.comment: Stakeholders map was prepared and seventeen (17) consultation and situation analyses events with relevant stakeholders were organized. The project objectives and implementation strategy were communicated to a total of 432 participants coming from 76 municipalities, the Ministry of Finance [MoF], the ZELS, and the Ministry of Local Self-Government [MLSG]. Basic Financial, Capacity Needs, Governance and Gender and Inter-ethnic Assessments including respective assessment tools were designed and their implementation was initiated. Participatory project document preparation process was initiated and the expectations of the local stakeholders against the initial project assumptions were validated. Cooperation agreement was concluded with the Association of the Finance Officers. The assessment tools (questionnaires and indicators) in practice will serve as (performance) indicators for selection of the municipalities. The work on the Training and Capacity Building Curriculum for the municipal councilors and municipal administration, was initiated. The Project Board was established.

location.activity-description: Development of watershed management plan for Strumica river basin

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Initial characterization of Strumica river basin is carried out Baseline flood risk data for the watershed collected and Preliminary Flood Risk Assessment prepared Strumica River Basin Management Council is established Proposal on optimal institutional / organizational setup for the future management of Strumica River Basin Proposal on future / long-term basin-scale monitoring system developed Strumica River basin Management Plan adopted

baseline.comment: No integrated river basin management plan for Strumica exists. There is no sufficient monitoring data to characterize the river basin, define reference conditions and establish ecological status of basin’s water bodies No flood risk assessment documentation in accordance with EU Floods Directive exists for the basin No modelling platforms are used for the management of basin’s water resources National water legislation isn’t harmonized with the EU Floods Directive No watershed management body for the Strumica River Basin exists There is no operational monitoring system for Strumica River Basin aligned with the Water Framework Directive/Law on Waters requirements

target.comment: • Finalization of the Strumica River Basin Management Plan • Completion of the Preliminary Flood Risk Assessment of Strumica River Basin • Implementation of a targeted monitoring programme for the Strumica River Basin • Formulation of proposals for introducing the flood risk management approach into national systems through harmonization with the EU Floods Directive

iati-activity.title: Strumica River Basin II phase
iati-activity.description: Implementation of the Management Plan for Strumica River Basin

location.name: Skopje
location.activity-description: Build disaster and climate resilience by increasing institutional capacity, mobilizing knowledge and transferring appropriate best practice innovation technologies

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Urban resilience action plan and climate change strategy for the City of Skopje in place. Gender considerations incorporated in the urban disaster and climate resilience action plans. # of targeted capacity strengthening programmes implemented. # of replications and scaling up of the existing mobile disaster risk reduction and climate change application # of ICT solutions for information sharing/public awareness raising on urban resilience, including solutions that take into consideration the needs of vulnerable categories of citizens, especially disabled persons.

baseline.comment: Lack of integrated urban disaster and climate resilience action plans in the country. Insufficient technical knowledge and expertise for preparation of integrated urban disaster and climate resilience plans. Ad-hoc integration of disaster and climate change issues into national policies and strategies. Low public awareness on urban resilience on disaster and climate risks. Low level of cooperation and information sharing between different level of stakeholders and organizations dealing with disastwer risk reduction; Poor integration of ICT led disaster risk reduction solutions for vulnerable categories of citizens, especially disabled persons.

target.comment: Draft Integrated Urban Resilience Action Plans for the City of Skopje developed with participation of men and women. Two targeted capacity strengthening programme for the key stakeholders implemented Inventory of Greenhouse gasses for City of Skopje as per the 2006 IPCC guidelines for two years (2008 and 2012) developed - database and narrative report. Stakeholder map with indicated key stakeholders and information flows developed. 10 local thematic groups for identification of priority vulnerable sectors established as a consultative mechanism for development of a Climate Change Strategy for the City of Skopje. Draft Climate Change Strategy for City of Skopje developed. Rapid Assessment of the current situation and needs for ICT for Urban Resilience conducted. Mobile DRR applications replication/scaling up initiated in the participating countries.

actual.comment: Inventory of Greenhouse gasses for City of Skopje as per the 2006 IPCC guidelines for two years (2008 and 2012) and mitigation narrative report developed. 15 foresight based stakeholder workshops to identify the vulnerable sectors and priorities for preparation of the strategy carried, 290 persons participated at the workshops ranging from high schools, municipal representatives, city administration and representatives from national institutions on local level. The key priorities and vulnerable sectors for development of the Climate Change Strategy for the City of Skopje and the action plan were identified. Rapid Assessment of the current situation and needs for ICT for Urban Resilience conducted.Analysis and recommendations for an integrated spatial platform for urban resilience were done based on the analysis of the existing and planned geo and spatial service and information databases in City of Skopje, and the participating institutions. The system for urban resilience of City of Skopje shall be with SOA (Service Oriented Architecture) and shall be divided in two parts: WEB GIS platform for urban resilience in City of Skopje and spatial data aggregator hosted in Crisis Management Centre. In MKD a mobile application for safe evacuation with using of QR codes was developed and has “Disaster Buddy” module that send the location and text to three contacts in case of crisis or disasters

iati-activity.title: Anti-Corruption/Transparency and Accountability
iati-activity.description: Umbrella programme to cover anti-corruption and rule of law activities at central and local levels.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Awareness raising/explosre/perr-to-peer exchanges of knowledge implemented Elements of the integrity system introduced/institutionalized in the Municipality of Tetovo.

baseline.comment: Lack of exposure of municipal staff to good practices on transparency/accountability/integrity. Lack of systemic tools in the municipality of Tetovo to address corruption risks and improve integrity.

target.comment: Facilitation of exchange of experiences or the Tetovo municipal staff on transparency and accountability local level practices with Western Balkans countries.

actual.comment: Tetovo municipal staff exposed to models and good practices relating to issues of transparency, accountability and resiliance to corruption in Croatia (as a recent EU member country).

target.comment: Introduction of a full-fledged integrity system in the Municipality of Tetovo.

actual.comment: The project has been suspended.

iati-activity.title: Rule of Law Programme
iati-activity.description: This is an Initiation Plan for the COMPREHENSIVE PROGRAMME FOR PROMOTION OF RULE OF LAW, INTEGRITY, TRANSPARENCY AND ACCOUNTABILITY AT CENTRAL AND LOCAL LEVELS” including anti-corruption work and support to rule of law EU accession agenda.

transaction.disbursement-channel: Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

indicator.title: Output Indicator

baseline.comment: -The rule of law agenda of Chapter 23 and 24 of the EU acquis, has been one of the key national priorities where UNDP has managed to provide support to the human and institutional capacity-building through the UNDP Regional Facility in Croatia. Institutions continued to rely on UNDP for supporting the rule of law agenda and the home affairs sector through access of knowledge, experiences and resources. -UNDP has established a long-standing partnership with the State Commission for Prevention of Corruption on policy design processes, but also on offering innovative models, tools and methodologies for addressing corruption risks at local level. -The State Commission for Prevention of Corruption is due to start preparing the new State Anti-Corruption Pagramme 2016-2010 by the end of the year and is need of being exposed to good practices that can be incorporated in the new Programme. - The country has been undergoing a political crisis and corruption has been on the agenda of high level dialogue between the political parties for overcoming the crisis and agreeing on future reforms.

target.comment: Project initiated in 2015

• Sector planning document on home affairs prepared with technical support from UNDP; • Support provided to the relevant anti-corruption bodies and stakeholders on maintaining the dialogue on the lessons learnt from the implementation of the current Anti-Corruption Programme and on avenues and priorities of the next anti-corruption policy reforms. • Good practices and tools on innovation in anti-corruption shared with the relevant anti-corruption bodies, with support from the UNDP Istanbul Regional Hub. • UNDP contribution provided to high level discussions for anti-corruption policy reforms.

actual.comment:
• Based on good practices and regional experiences, technical assistance was provided to the Ministry of Internal Affairs for preparation of the sector planning home affairs document, including with support through the expertise from the Regional Facility in Croatia. The final outcome of the process was a mid-term EU home affairs sector planning document which defined priority areas that might be financed under IPA II and prepare the ground for its proper management, monitoring and evaluation.
• At the beginning of the year, UNDP supported the State Anti-Corruption Commission on organizing a debate to reflect on the progress of implementation of the State Programme for Prevention of Corruption. The debate provided space for the relevant stakeholders to discuss the challenges and lessons learnt from the implementation of the current Anti-Corruption Programme and the avenues and priorities for the next anti-corruption policy reforms.
• UNDP’s specific contribution to the anti-corruption dialogue was focused on sharing of best practices on application of innovative approaches and experiences in prevention of corruption at local level in cooperation with the UNDP Regional Hub in Istanbul.
• Acknowledging the complexities pertaining to the current political environment in the country, UNDP continued advocating for transparency, accountability and prevention of corruption, particularly at local level through its other local development/decentralization projects, while offering technical assistance to the high-level political working group on the upcoming anti-corruption policy discussions.

iati-activity.title: Emergency Flood Coordination Support
iati-activity.description: The project will focus on strengthening coordination mechanisms on national and local level for flood response and early recovery.

iati-activity.title: Emergency Floods Coordination
iati-activity.description: The project will focus on strengthening coordination mechanisms on national and local level for flood response and early recovery. The project will also support the coordinating efforts for development of a more comprehensive flood recovery programme.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
At least 5 employees of the emergency agencies and other relevant institutions of the crisis management system, and 5 members of the UN Country Team and Disaster Management Team trained on performing a Post Disaster Needs Assessment
Comprehensive floods recovery programme for the affected communities in the Pelagonia region in place

baseline.comment: Low capacity for performing Post Disaster Needs Assessment in the country Insufficient capacity for planning and execution of flood recovery initiatives and measures.

target.comment: In-depth floods risk assessment for the River Crna river basin carried out and recommendations for floods risk mitigation measures developed Flood recovery programme for the affected communities in Pelagonija region prepared Capacities for disaster response and recovery of the UN Country Team and the key national institutions enhanced through provision of a targeted Post Disaster Needs Assessment training

actual.comment:
In-depth floods risk assessment for the River Crna Rriver Basin and Pena River (Polog region) carried out and recommendations for floods risk mitigation measures developed;
Flood recovery programme for the affected communities in Pelagonija region prepared and resources for implementation of priority recovery measures mobilized.

iati-activity.title: EU Floods Recovery Programme (Transport)
iati-activity.description: Rehabilitation of infrastructure after floods in the country

iati-activity.title: Floods Recovery Programme
iati-activity.description: The country and its citizens benefit from the reconstructed transport infrastructure, its increased resilience to floods and improved floods mitigation potential

transaction.disbursement-channel: Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
Number of reconstructed bridges/culverts damaged by the floods (at least 4 in total length of 161,67m)
Number and length of recovered roads by category of road and regions (at least 16 km of local roads in four affected municipalities)
At least one landslide on regional/local roads stabilized
# of Knowledge products and public awareness raising material
Guidance document for incorporation of the “built back better” in place

baseline.comment:
42.8 % of total damages and losses occurred in the infrastructure sector due to the floods that occured in 2015 . Increased risk and vulnerability of transport infrastructure through instability of sloping terrain that may cause further landslides, the occurrence of aftershocks following an earthquake, and possible occurrence of further intensive rainfall and flooding
Limited knowledge about the contemporary approaches for recovery of infrastructure in accordance with the ‘build back better’ principles. The current design approaches often do not take the importance of enhancing resilience of the infrastructure into consideration

target.comment: Sign of the Project Document with the EU Delegation and initiate activities for the start up of the project

actual.comment: The Project Document with the EU Delegation signed on 20 November and activities to start up da project initiated.
